title: 3 Simple Ways to Copy Contents of One Hard Drive to a New Hard Drive

steps.title: Make sure that you have the new hard drive.
steps.content: Make sure that you have the new hard drive. Your new hard drive must be larger than the space that's currently occupied on the hard drive that you want to copy. If you're creating a clone of your hard drive, the new hard drive must be at least the same size. There are two types of hard drives to which you can copy your old hard drive's contents: Internal - A hard drive that sits inside of your computer's housing. External - A hard drive that connects to your computer via a USB cable. Most external hard drives will work on any computer, though in some cases you must format the hard drive before using it.

steps.title: Buy an adapter for your hard drive if necessary.
steps.content: Buy an adapter for your hard drive if necessary. If you're copying your hard drive's contents onto another internal drive, you'll need a USB adapter so that you can attach the new hard drive to your computer. There are two types of hard drive connections: SATA, which has a narrow cable attaching the connector to the drive, and IDE, which has a several-inch-wide cable attaching the connector to the drive. You can buy SATA-to-USB and IDE-to-USB adapters online or in tech department stores such as Best Buy. If you're using a Mac, make sure that you get a USB-C to SATA/IDE adapter rather than a USB 3.0 version, as Macs no longer have USB 3.0 ports.

steps.title: Back up your computer
steps.content: Back up your computer . Creating a backup on a separate drive is optional, but recommended in case something goes wrong during the copying.

steps.title: Attach your hard drive to your computer.
steps.content: Attach your hard drive to your computer. Plug the hard drive's USB cable into the computer's USB slot. If you're using an internal hard drive with an adapter, make sure that the hard drive is firmly connected to the adapter as well. If you're using an external hard drive on a Mac, you may need to format the drive before you can store your hard drive's contents on it.

steps.title: Open the Todo website.
steps.content: Open the Todo website. Go to https://www.easeus.com/backup-software/tb-free.html in your browser.

steps.title: Click DOWNLOAD NOW.
steps.content: Click DOWNLOAD NOW . It's a dark-blue button in the middle of the page.

steps.title: Click Download.
steps.content: Click Download . Do so below the "Free" heading. A pop-up window will appear.

steps.title: Enter your email address and click SUBMIT.
steps.content: Enter your email address and click SUBMIT . You'll do this in the pop-up window.

steps.title: Click the Download EaseUS Todo Backup Free link.
steps.content: Click the Download EaseUS Todo Backup Free link. It's at the top of the window. The EaseUS Todo setup file will begin downloading to your computer.

steps.title: Install Todo.
steps.content: Install Todo. Double-click the Todo setup file, then do the following: Click Yes when prompted. Select a language and click OK Click Next Click Accept Click Next Uncheck the "Join in the Customer Experience Improvement program" box and click Next Click Next Uncheck the "McAfee" box and click Next

steps.title: Click Finish when prompted.
steps.content: Click Finish when prompted. This will complete the installation and launch Todo.

steps.title: Click Later when prompted.
steps.content: Click Later when prompted. It's in the bottom-right corner of the window.

steps.title: Click the Clone tab.
steps.content: Click the Clone tab. You'll find this at the top of the window.

steps.title: Check the "Hard disk" box.
steps.content: Check the "Hard disk" box. It's in the upper-left corner of the window.

steps.title: Click Next.
steps.content: Click Next . This is in the bottom-right corner of the window.

steps.title: Select your new hard drive.
steps.content: Select your new hard drive. Scroll down and check the "Hard disk" box near the bottom of the window. This should be your attached hard drive. If your new hard drive is a solid state drive (SSD), click Advanced options in the bottom-left corner and then click Optimize for SSD in the pop-up menu before proceeding.

steps.title: Click Next.
steps.content: Click Next .

steps.title: Click Proceed.
steps.content: Click Proceed . It's in the bottom-right corner of the window.

steps.title: Click OK when prompted.
steps.content: Click OK when prompted. Doing so will prompt Todo to begin copying your hard drive's contents onto the attached hard drive.

steps.title: Wait for your hard drive to finish copying.
steps.content: Wait for your hard drive to finish copying. This can take several hours to complete. Once the process finishes, Todo will notify you.

steps.title: Eject your hard drive from your computer.
steps.content: Eject your hard drive from your computer. Click the flash drive-shaped icon in the bottom-right corner of the screen and click Eject in the pop-up menu, then physically detach the drive from your computer when Windows tells you that it's safe to do so. You may first have to click ^ in the bottom-right corner of the screen to view the flash drive icon.

steps.title: Restart your Mac.
steps.content: Restart your Mac. Click the Apple menu , click Restart... , and click Restart Now when prompted.

steps.title: Press and hold ⌘ Command+R.
steps.content: Press and hold ⌘ Command + R . Do so immediately after your Mac begins to restart.

steps.title: Wait for the Apple logo to appear.
steps.content: Wait for the Apple logo to appear. You should keep holding down the keys during this time. You may also see a spinning globe appear here.

steps.title: Release ⌘ Command and R.
steps.content: Release ⌘ Command and R . As soon as you see the spinning globe or Earth icon, release the keys. You should now be at the recovery screen.

steps.title: Click Disk Utility.
steps.content: Click Disk Utility . It's a grey hard drive icon in the window.

steps.title: Click Continue.
steps.content: Click Continue . This is in the bottom-right corner of the screen.

steps.title: Select your other hard drive.
steps.content: Select your other hard drive. Click the attached hard drive's name in the top-left side of the page.

steps.title: Click Edit.
steps.content: Click Edit . This menu item is at the top of the Mac's screen. A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Restore….
steps.content: Click Restore… . It's at the top of the drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click the "Restore from" drop-down box.
steps.content: Click the "Restore from" drop-down box. You'll find this in the middle of the window.

steps.title: Select your Mac's hard drive.
steps.content: Select your Mac's hard drive. It's in the drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click Restore.
steps.content: Click Restore . This blue button is in the bottom-right corner of the window. Clicking it prompts your hard drive to begin backing up to the external hard drive. This can take several hours to complete. If you get a "Restoration Failed" error, turn off FileVault and try again.

steps.title: Click Done when prompted.
steps.content: Click Done when prompted. It's in the bottom-right corner of the window. Your original hard drive is now backed up to the new hard drive.

steps.title: Close Disk Utility.
steps.content: Close Disk Utility. Click the red circle in the top-left corner of the window.

steps.title: Click Choose Startup Disk….
steps.content: Click Choose Startup Disk… . It's on the left side of the window.

steps.title: Select your original hard drive and click Restart.
steps.content: Select your original hard drive and click Restart . Doing so will restart your computer.

steps.title: Open the Apple menu .
steps.content: Open the Apple menu . Click the Apple logo in the top-left corner of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Click System Preferences….
steps.content: Click System Preferences… . It's near the top of the Apple drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click Startup Disk.
steps.content: Click Startup Disk . This grey hard drive icon is in the middle of the System Preferences window.

steps.title: Unlock the menu.
steps.content: Unlock the menu. Click the lock icon in the bottom-left corner of the window, then enter your account password when prompted.

steps.title: Select your new hard drive.
steps.content: Select your new hard drive. Click the yellow attached hard drive's icon at the top of the window.

steps.title: Click Restart….
steps.content: Click Restart… . It's on the right side of the window.

steps.title: Click Restart when prompted.
steps.content: Click Restart when prompted. Doing so will reboot your Mac from the new hard drive, which will ensure that the hard drive is used as a bootable drive on any other Mac.

steps.title: Wait for your Mac to finish restarting.
steps.content: Wait for your Mac to finish restarting. This can take several minutes.

steps.title: Switch back to the original hard drive.
steps.content: Switch back to the original hard drive. To do so: Open the Apple menu Click System Preferences... Click Startup Disk Unlock the menu. Click the original (grey) hard drive. Click Restart... , then click Restart when prompted.

steps.title: Eject your new hard drive.
steps.content: Eject your new hard drive. Open Finder and click the triangle-shaped "Eject" button to the right of your attached hard drive's name on the left side of the window. When prompted, you can physically detach the drive from your Mac.
